X-Yahoo-Profile: joeraii

> Joseph Reisinger experimented with Tic-Tac-Toe and a modular version
> of NEAT.  Did you normalize for chromosome size in your experiments,
> Joseph?  Or was N always set to 1 and the compatibility threshold
> value always set to either 3.0 or 4.0?

I was actually going to chime in about this. My method was different than
the other two that were previously mentioned (fixed normalized
compatibility threshold, and fixed number of species).

For modular NEAT, chromosome and module compatibility are computed
similarly to how Ken does it with NEAT, but instead of keeping a fixed
value for the species compatibility threshold, mine floats. Basically,
every epoch approximates an "average species distance" value, and that is
used to determine compatibility. So, if topologies are diverging, the
value will increase with time, and if they are converging, it will shrink.

What is nice about this is that you don't have to worry about what the
optimal value is for species or for compatibility, it will be determined
at runtime.

The main problem is approximating species distance. One way is to compare
all the chromosomes. I just keep a running average of the previous 10 or
20 values and approximate the new values from the chromosomes and modules
that are being added to species that generation.

Joe

-- 

Joseph Reisinger
